body.p: Which of the following p-values will give the strongest evidence against H0?

response.feedback: Incorrect. A large p-value (like 0.31) indicates that the sample result is likely to occur in random sampling from a population in which H0 is true. So a large p-value provides very weak evidence against H0. Click here to see graphs illustrating these p-values.
Incorrect. The smaller the p-value, the stronger the evidence against H0.

Correct. A small p-value (like 0.02) indicates that the sample result is not likely to occur in random sampling from a population in which H0 is true. So a small p-value provides strong evidence against H0. Click here to see graphs illustrating these p-values.

part.hint: Think about p-value as an area under the normal distribution of z-scores. If the area is large, results more extreme than the data are common from a population for which H0 is true.
Click here to see graphs illustrating p-values.
The smaller the p-value, the stronger the evidence against H0.
